_schema: Books - status: reading | completed | want-to-read, rating: 1-5

books.title: Stoner
books.author: John Williams
books.thoughts: A quiet life lived fully. Fardin's all-time favorite - the kind of book that makes you reconsider what 'success' actually means.

books.title: Crime and Punishment
books.author: Fyodor Dostoevsky
books.thoughts: Dostoevsky gets inside a mind destroying itself. The psychology here is more real than most modern novels.

books.title: Notes from Underground
books.author: Fyodor Dostoevsky
books.thoughts: The original anti-hero. Uncomfortable because Fardin recognized parts of himself in the Underground Man.

books.title: White Nights
books.author: Fyodor Dostoevsky
books.thoughts: Dostoevsky's most romantic work. Brief, devastating, beautiful.

books.title: One Hundred Years of Solitude
books.author: Gabriel Garcia Marquez
books.thoughts: Magical realism that feels more real than realism. Every page is a fever dream.

books.title: The Birth of Tragedy
books.author: Friedrich Nietzsche
books.thoughts: Apollonian vs Dionysian - a framework for understanding art, culture, and oneself.

books.title: Man's Search for Meaning
books.author: Viktor Frankl
books.thoughts: A book that puts everything in perspective. Suffering is inevitable; meaning is a choice.

books.title: The Stranger
books.author: Albert Camus
books.thoughts: Meursault's detachment is either terrifying or liberating, depending on when you read it.

books.title: Five Dialogues
books.author: Plato
books.thoughts: Socrates in action. The Apology alone is worth the price - a man choosing death over compromise.

books.title: Don Quixote
books.author: Miguel de Cervantes
books.thoughts: The first modern novel. Don Quixote is mad, yes - but also the only one truly alive.

books.title: The Count of Monte Cristo
books.author: Alexandre Dumas
books.thoughts: The ultimate revenge fantasy. 1000+ pages that never drag for a second.

books.title: Man and His Symbols
books.author: Carl Jung
books.thoughts: Jung's accessible entry point. Fardin came to this through Peterson, stayed for the depth.

books.title: The Way of Zen
books.author: Alan Watts
books.thoughts: Eastern philosophy made accessible. Changed how Fardin thinks about thinking.

books.title: The Metamorphosis
books.author: Franz Kafka
books.thoughts: Alienation made literal. Kafka's absurdism hits different in the age of remote work.

books.title: Siddhartha
books.author: Hermann Hesse
books.thoughts: Everyone must find their own path. The river metaphor stays with you.

books.title: Septology
books.author: Jon Fosse
books.thoughts: Nobel Prize-winning stream of consciousness. Seven parts, one sentence, infinite depth.

books.title: Flowers for Algernon
books.author: Daniel Keyes
books.thoughts: Intelligence vs wisdom. The gradual decline is devastating.

books.author: George Orwell
books.thoughts: Gets more relevant every year. The appendix on Newspeak is the scariest part.

books.title: King Lear
books.author: William Shakespeare
books.thoughts: Shakespeare's darkest tragedy. Pride, aging, and the impossibility of truly knowing another person.

books.title: The Book of Job
books.author: Anonymous
books.thoughts: The oldest philosophical text. Why do the righteous suffer? No easy answers - just the question itself.

books.title: The Alchemist
books.author: Paulo Coelho
books.thoughts: Simple but not simplistic. The universe conspiring thing sounds cheesy until you live it.

books.title: The Great Gatsby
books.author: F. Scott Fitzgerald
books.thoughts: The American Dream dissected. That green light still means something.

books.title: The Picture of Dorian Gray
books.author: Oscar Wilde
books.thoughts: Wilde at his most decadent. Every epigram is quotable.

books.title: The Sorrows of Young Werther
books.author: Johann Wolfgang von Goethe
books.thoughts: The book that invented Romanticism - and caused a suicide epidemic. Handle with care.
